author: Rollmottle
content:
Been trying to think of a way in to the question about what I did without being completely frustrating or giving a list of moves that don't mean anything outside of the context of being in my chair, hearing what and how I hear.

This process for this song is like any other...listen for what the song needs and act accordingly. That's the frustrating answer but it's also true. What did you do? "I mastered it." lol

But I know that's not what you're asking. For a track like this, I'm primarily focused on the vocal and how it's sitting and feeling. The vocal performance is incredibly dynamic and intimate. This one had some ringy stuff through 2.5k and in the upper mid range that I felt was detracting from the "fireside" intimacy. The goal was to take off some of the edge without stepping on the presence. That was a combo of RX and EQ. 

On this song, I did an analog pass because I am usually able to manage to get the balance of presence and de-edge I'm looking for very quickly. Since time was of the essence here, that was the move. Couple of moves on Equilibrium digitally before the Gyraf and Porter Grinder in the analog chain. The "trickiest" thing I did here was flip the Porter Grinder into M/S to bring the vocal closer into the center (by cutting!) and to push the mellotron and atmospherics to the sides (by boosting). All very subtle stuff.

So, there were some moves here, but the moves were all in service of the feeling the song was telling me it needed. We talk a lot about monitoring here. When you can connect to the song and walk around inside of it, it's much easier to know what you need to do (or not to do) to bring it to life.

author: Paris Lee
content:
Was rearranging some stuff last night, I’m selling a lot of gear coming up. And just distilling my analog rig to the Pure essentials.
Figured I’d share 
Some cool stuff here, Frank Lacey made items like the Barry Porter Net Eq and his own compressor, also a classic FX 384 with modified attack and release times, and a Maselec of course 🙂

author: Paris Lee
content:
Very exciting happenings…
Currently amazed at how the ADI does what it claims re: auto sensing balanced or unbalanced loads (dictating how it adjusts the internal impedance) , and giving the same sonic result either way. An amazing time today putting my Balanced MEA 2 on insert 1, then running into my Bal/Unbal Frank Lacy HPF to the Lacy Porter on insert 2. The original setup includes a way to balance the signal back before the A/D, and i have that, but it’s an extra piece of equipment that i never need/use. This was the feature that drew me to the ADI to be honest and made me pull the trigger…so does the ADI perform as it should…? Damn effing straight it does. What a box!!!! Nothing in, balanced signal…great…both eq’s in…no timbral change…either eq in by itself…no timbral change (other than what the boxes themselves would impart…but being a passive switcher and these boxes being what they are…and this converter what it is…there’s not a obtrusive timbral change imparted). 

Balanced…unbalanced…zero fucks given…what a box!

author: Slow Hand
content:
When it comes to loudness, a big unlock happened for me when I realized that a lot of perceived loudness comes from the frequency balance of instruments or groups. There's a sort of "center of gravity" for the frequency of instruments. Individual instruments did not need as much low end as I once thought. I realized that I could push more energy up into the mids and upper-mids. Instruments could be leaner and biting. Much more than I thought tolerable. This has a few positive effects:

1. The sounds will cut more and be articulate in the mix (if desired).

2. Low-end buildup is the first thing that's going to hit your limiter. Shifting the energy up the frequency spectrum buys you more space before your limiter kicks in. Thus your overall mix can be louder.

3. Your low-end instruments will no longer compete to feel powerful. Therefore they do not need to be as loud in an absolute/voltage sense. Meanwhile, your midrange-y instruments that were once lean and bite-y in isolation are supplemented by your low-end instruments and feel whole again.

author: Rollmottle
content:
1. Pull in all pre-masters into one session. Name all regions and order it as intended. 
2. Initial pre-master listen to gain the material to be generally the same RMS (material dependent of course) so that it hits my analog chain at a consistent level....draw in any obviously needed volume automation. 
3. Start mastering....which for me is two steps...the actual deep pre-master listen to understand what the track may need. It is as this stage where I'll address any technical issues (pre-analog processing, RX work, additional automation refinement, etc.). Then comes the actual master processing step and the subsequent master capture.

author: cian riordan
content: Ruairi's gonna come on here and shellac me in a few, but I'm of reasonably stable mind and don't believe that people are setting up proper tests when matching converters (level calibration, having the ability to actually go back and forth between them instantly, etc). The idea that there's a dramatic sonic difference between any reasonably spec'd modern converter is just insane to me. I've gone down the rabbit hole for years with comparative listening with converters, clocks, etc and I've built my own conclusions --  I hope everyone here has a chance to do that as well instead of just taking people's word on the internet for how many thousands of dollars people should spend on boutique A/D/A.

author: Berlin
content: I sold all my outboard gear last year and went 100 in the box, best decision I’ve made in a minute. Only second to joining this discord.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
In modern record making clipping and limiting on the buss is a huge part of the overall sound and feel of a record. Kendrick for example never heard his productions, mixes or masters without it. Clipping has an energy in the kicks and snares that was built a certain way, limiting has rounding and smoothing characteristics and often "holds" the track in a particular way. You can't just bypass one , or the other or both without huge changes in groove, balance, tone and feel. (Swapping limiters for something *safer* can be equally damaging) 

What does clipping actually do? It creates square waves at the extreme (for the duration of the clipping)

What is a square wave? It is a fundamental with a bunch of odd harmonics trailing off in level

What happens when you low pass the square wave at the converter reconstruction filter, lathe low pass etc? It is no longer a square wave

Does cutting this no longer square wave to a disc for brief periods present challenges and cause extra momentary distortion? Yes

Is that trade off worth while? I believe so and have itterated on this belief across hundreds and hundreds of projects cut and pressed to vinyl and then compared carefully with the original digital files

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: Well eventually (after many hours of probing everything, trying different adapter cables…) I found it was a ground loop being caused by the interface’s AES I/O even though it’s supposedly floating. Gets very unhappy depending on what touches ground. Ended up having to have one AES cable going through one format converter which entirely separates ground and another wired differently (pin 1 and 2 instead of 2 and 3 to convert to spdif). Solves the grounding issues

author: cian riordan
content: Because I A/B'd the Lynx Hilo, my Orion, the Grace DAC, and a Topping D30 and they all sounded the goddamned same. So for utility sake, having everything come out the Grace DAC makes a lot more sense for a sane, working mix environment.

author: cian riordan
content: My guess on this is that if that sub material wasn't on the final mixes, then theres likely tube misbehaving on an MS outboard compressor (unfairchild, etc). As for keeping your low end in mono -- that was a rule of thumb for years to ensure translation outside of the studio for various formats. With digital recording & reproduction... it's not an issue if you do it thoughtfully.

author: Halliemmelton

author: Berlin
content: Digital "Vinyl Premasters" where an ME might mono sum the low end or not use a limiter, or do some of those types of "vinyl master" tricks, are honestly getting into the minutia and we are talking about 1-2% gains in the final result.. It should be mentioned also that the cutting engineer will also have their own cutting mastering chain of various outboard units that are going to try and catch some of those "issues" that might be presented. Best practice, and others might disagree with me, in my house is to prepare the vinyl sides and a PQ sheet, QC the export, and ship it. Don't fuck with an approved master/project too much. - Partner with a great lacquer engineer, and the Master will be dope.

author: LAPhill
content: I think most of us with a few extra reps around the sun would usually point to something we’ve done BEFORE getting the baller gear as our best/most popular work. Good gear can help once you know what you’re doing, but good ideas and intention have nothing to do with what DAC you have.

author: cian riordan
content: Absolutely. I try to be as agnostic as possible between audio brands of various cache (I think my switch from ATC to PMC is solid proof of this). I'd be happy to spend money on a better DAC if it made a reasonable impact in my monitoring environment or even more importantly, the quality of my work. I had every intention of using the better spec'ing Topping instead of the Grace but when I A/B'd them, they sounded near identical and I would go on to say that the Topping sounded slightly worse. The Hilo and Orion were just identical. Different story when replaced my Dangerous Monitor ST with the Grace m905... that was a big difference. Same with the ATCs vs PMCs... instant. Huge. But DACs? I'm firmly in the 'solved problem' camp. Insanity to me that people working out of bedrooms with wall panels claiming they can hear massive differences between these boxes... I genuinely want to call shenanigans.

author: Berlin
content:
speaking of raising rates and not listening. a few years back I raised my rates and lost an artist, they then went else where for their master, got it mastered, and got v1 back - set up in their studio, jamming it loud, and then when the bridge of track 1 hit, there was an iphone ring tone BLASTING, distorted, and it scared them to death and almost blew up their studio... Needless to say they came back quickly, paid my rate. 

Still have always wondering what happened with those masters - all I can figure is their phone was synced to their computer, they were mastering out of the box, and their computer chose the DAC for their mastering chain, got a call while running masters without monitoring, didn't QC and just hit send.

author: Rollmottle
content:
I don’t have the volume of work some others here do so I am more likely to have the time others don’t have to send something to outboard. With that said, I am digital 95% of the time. On the rare occasion I use my outboard, it will more than likely be a single. I will always capture the print pre-limiter. And if I need to tweak something, it will be done with a digital EQ.

These days, I’d never do an album where all the tracks go out. It takes too much time to document, extra time to capture, and when the inevitable mix swap comes, extra time to recall, reprint etc. I used to, but it doesn’t scale well if you have any meaningful volume of work where recalls or in flight projects become prohibitive to you handling more than one work stream for multiple clients at once.

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: I have a device in my studio which does nothing except plug into the wall (and has on/off switch). Changes how everything in my system sounds. Measure AD/DA loop with REW and you’ll see no difference at all yet if I print files others can pick out which has the device on/off. Took a lot of analysis for me to figure out what it does is change the shape of the noise floor on my DAC (and/or ADC)

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: For our chain the sweetspot was leaking around -6dB FS on the converter. Our EQs and line amps are all low noise/high headroom so it was governed solely by the analog color piece - modded SSL, MDE, Fearn, Gyraf or whatever. What I like about ghat level is that I can go up or down easily and find that perfect amount of color

author: Paris Lee
content:
@Stefan Hi Stephen, this is a great question! 
There are two issues at play here: One the more obvious, sending the signal to multiple A/D’s, and then, maybe a little less obvious: the issue of how your system is being clocked, and whether the A/D you’re auditioning is exerting maximum performance based on these conditions. Personally, to feed multiple converters, I use a Maselec MTC 1x console. This offers two identical outputs. So the analog signal part of that is solved right there. There are other ways to address this problem like outboard switchers. 

But here’s the real problem, clocking. *Generally*, and when i say generally probably in almost 100 percent of cases, the A/D converter sounds its best when it is the master clock of your system. Of course there are *certain* converters that *may* benefit from external clocking, but I’m not jumping into that can of worms. You can read ENDLESS arguments on Gearspace about this. 

I’ll say up front that I think clock sounds best just getting transferred straight through the AES audio feed to your interface, vs using a BNC output to your system, but again, I could get pushback there, that’s my opinion. 

So- let’s get to it, you have two A/D’s running AES feeds into your interface. Now, on your interface itself- you need to choose what AES feed your choosing to Sync to- so you’re going to choose one aes feed, or the other. This doesn’t *preclude you* from solo’ing each feed in your DAW. But the main thing here is that when you audition one converter, you need to also go to your control panel of your interface and select that AES feed to sync if you really want to hear the correct sound. 

In sum, I would do it this way and record a 30-45 pass of each. Then audition them that way (i use comp lanes on the same track to achieve this).

Another possible way to do this is having an outboard aes switcher like a z sys and switching the converters to the same aes output. Hope this helps!

author: Paris Lee
content:
The EQ section on the MLA 4 is fucking excellent and different than conventional eq sound. Bump the mid band half a db (top of low range to a mid range 3k-8k. Killer

It has a great hi shelf de-esser 

Turning down 100-200hz half a db can really relax the low end that a shelf on other eq’s does not do.

The eq is where it’s at. The compression is just a slight slight squeezer. 

Low band on dance tracks *GENTLY* no visible GR or rare GR lights 
Hi band de ess - starting point 3m attack 50m release)

author: Moses Mastering
content: yes and yes.. as a analog lover and user of it still for the last 8 years.. and i continue to buy things... its just a tool... .so it has to not only fit in the context of the project sonically but also in the context of "getting the project done" on time/budget. etc... sometimes labels will send me same day stuff and as much as I would love to run the record thru the analog chain, I know in two hours they will send me a new mix with a new vocal lol.. casue they are behind and someone missed something haha ... sometimes there is literally not enough time in a day even if you wanted to run analog due to project constraints. Is this good or bad? I don't know haha.. but its part of the gig I have found and something i accepted. Ironically i made a career and enough money off plugins lol to then buy all this gear lol... at this stage the gear is more for me and the way I like to work when time allows it. I adore gear.. but workflow and turn around time makes it sometimes impossible to use.

author: David Fuller
content: it depends on the converter if I'm honest. Some handle peaks better than others

author: Eric Martin
content: when the peak happens in-between sample points it can be over full scale in decoding the analog signal out of the digital one

author: Eric Martin
content: and then the converter on the end users device clips, and sometimes the converters have clipping protection built into the firmware so that can’t happen and that further crunches up the audio

author: David Fuller
content: Yeah so basically the converter has extra headroom before it runs into the supply rails

author: BillyC
content: @Eric Martin @David Fuller I understand how digital clipping can occur, but I'm still not sure I understand how it's theoretically possible to have true headroom above 0dBfs. In my mind the converter either has a nifty way of limiting intersample peaks, or the converter is simply scaling the signal down by -2.5dBfs.

author: BillyC
content: Again, I can conceive of ISPs. My question is even simpler: Isn't a converter company claiming to have *true* 2.5dB above full scale being a bit disingenuous? Doesn't that actually only mean they have a good sounding way limiting ISPs up to 2.5dB above full scale? In other words, "yeah this exactly 6' person will absolutely fit into our exactly 6' tall room...right after we take off his shoes and give him a clean buzz cut." Maybe my question is more semantic?

author: Eric Martin
content:
That is based on how the manufacturers calibrate where full scale is in terms of output which you’ll see referred to in a different language excuse the output is designed in volts not db, so in terms of voltage they’ll be able to cleanly supply more voltage than is necessary so that playback is always sounding as intended.

IE 0dbfs = 2.2 Volts peak to peak(positive and negative)

And lets say the amplifier can reproduce 3  Volts peak to peak, they’ve designed the device to handle any overs without distortion.

All of this is highly technical but involves maths and actual “audio engineering” in the geekiest of the geekery.

@David Fuller will understand much better than I do about it

author: David Fuller
content: it's just the rail voltage being above the maximum calibrated output

author: David Fuller
content: Matthias from RME explaining it better than I could

author: David Fuller
content: tl;dr: AKM chips have extra headroom above the voltage level that AKM decides is full scale, so the converter itself cannot clip with lower ISPs. Given good analog side engineering around that, it won't clip until it hits about +2dBFS - and the clipping behavior is pretty benign compared to the utter tomfuckery that is ESS

author: Zach Hughes
content: Folks, I have a question for the group. Would love to get a mastering engineers perspective. I'm curious what is the rationale behind masters clipping output converters and leaving in true peaks that exceed 0dBFS? I get that clipping converters can sound cool / desirable, but why not achieve the clipping you want and then print a final master under zero? Why risk a consumer product crapping out during playback and adding potential distortion and why totally disregard pretty much every DSP's recommendation that true peaks not exceed -1 for the encoding process? I'm noticing that a ton of major label releases are peaking above zero with loudness normalization turned off on Spotify.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: 1) The DAC outputs full scale and is attenuated in teh analog domain

author: Bonati12461
content: Oh - I have one big gripe about the RME - the unbalanced / balanced headphone option on the front panel. For a regular ol' set of phones you just plugin into the 1/4" TRS jack - for balanced you to use _both_ sets of TRS jacks.  You really have to make your own adapter cable. In my case that was a dual TRS to 4 pin XLR adapter that hooked to a balanced headphone cable I already had. I make cables all the time but it was still kind of a pain. They just give you a pinout in the manual, ha. Not an easy adapter to find if you can't make shit.

content:
I don’t know Gerhard…I’ll take your word for it 😂 but I really enjoy your mastering and your credits speak for themselves.

I love that people like you exist in the world and push boundaries of what’s possible. But to tie to maybe a literal example…I have a Massive Passive. It’s like 75 percent of what I wish it was. And it may well be possible for me to learn and build a better version of it with my background knowledge, not constrained by the variables Manley is.

But as you know, it would take YEARS of studying, trial/error/etc. maybe I end up with a better EQ. But I could also argue that I could have spent all that time just making records and I’d be much better off as a mastering engineer in long run, even with a “worse” EQ.

That’s an extreme black/white example, but I’ve got some big life changes coming and I’m really trying to reevaluate where my time is best spent and how it relates to my long term goals.

You and Ruairi straddle two very specific and niche worlds so was just looking for insight on how you handle your balance! How specific are you with your time management when you go down rabbit holes? And how that relates to your mastering goals

author: spectrummasters
content: Yep fair . So , a db expansion post catching peaks because I want to be loud but improve  the dynamics a little . Just want to open the mix up. Hence idea of  eq and expansion moves . The spectral shaper isn’t visibly working it’s in a de ess range really . The saturation in their mix sounds good , kind of sleazy and cool for the vocal so I don’t want to turn in something too clean . I thought mono <40 hz to pin the low end down  for want of a better phrase @@

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Yep, again I went deep on this maybe 3 years ago and it’s all hazy now. But they are basically throwing away the bottom bits of the audio (so with 16 bit that means any information from -96 dBFS up to —84 dBFS). Then they use that space to encode a fold down of information above 20k derived from high res source material. The hand waving Gerhard refers to is their claim to have a special “apodizing”filter that corrects for the phase shift in AD converters. This is actually impossible without knowing the exact AD, brothers in arms was recorded on ancient 3M digital machines with analog anti alias filters, very different to a kid with an Apollo with a Cirrus AD today

author: austenballard
content: Oh yeah, I read that conversation. I'm personally inclined to believe you, not because I'm gullible to snake oil (though I'm certainly just as gullible as anyone else when it comes to stuff I don't fully understand) but because I had the privilege of knowing a very intelligent man many years ago who explained to me how electrical currents flow and their impacts on components. This has since been supplemented by a friend who designs audio hardware linking me to a reputable article discussing the effects of minor fluctuations in current on variables like jitter, THD, and dither noise in ADC and DAC hardware. I look forward to seeing your results.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Super common to get alts printed at the wrong level (recalled outboard) or out of sync with main master. And as @hebakadry said cleanup can be worse on exposed A cappella etc

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: I’d like to share a little cautionary tale from my 3 hours spent troubleshooting today. I’ve been printing through AD/DA looping using an ADI-2 (so single unit). Went to use a different DA. Got horrible ground loop. Very strange behaviour (if I touch this or touch ground of this cable to this ground the noise floor changes in this way…). Made no sense since both converters use brick supply with no ground and my interface feeding them supposedly has transformer coupled outputs and inputs (AES) which I confirmed aren’t tied to ground.

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: Rough plan is DAC (+24 but can drop down), line amp, SPL width circuit (op amps + tube, xformerless) adjusted to handle +24, Davelizer (+24), BP (+24), SSL (I assume needs to run lower, haven’t looked into it), *insert other gear here * (I’d like to clone an OCL-2 someday…), selectable transformers with some kind of gain for driving potentially followed by a tube buffer with additional transformer (LL5402), line amp 2, ADC (+24, adjustable)

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: The noise floor of modern converters and clean analog gear is really low. So we can avoid worrying about that too much

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I’m terms of our upper limit, undesirable clipping that is something we have some control over with most modern converters - we can adjust the analog level at which they clip - Gerhard mentioned +24 in his case

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: But once we are using an analog chain we are looking for color, color that comes with noise l, noise which isn’t doesn’t matter much in the kind of loud records we often make

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: If I was starting over I’d be looking at unbalanced straight from the DAC or the best possible differential input stages - go down the Bruno rabbit hole

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: E.g. my Davelizer is worlds different from DMG and so far I haven’t been able to manipulate a chain with DMG (like DMG + converter loop) to match

author: David Fuller
content: This is getting really deep in the weeds but certain types of cap will behave differently with polarization voltage vs without

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: In the past I’ve tested on things like mics but this time it was just a converter loop with a single cap in line. Unfortunately I missed a 0 in one of my formulas so the cutoff ended up being at 80Hz instead of closer to 8Hz and the small variations between the caps created +/- around 0.2dB in the rolloffs making any blind testing not really valid. I’d say there a still other audible differences but can’t definitively stand behind that. I was hoping those variations would be well below 20Hz. Just need to get some bigger caps now…

content:
Since I'm on one today: another gear question ** shudders **

Does anyone have experience with both a Fearn VT-5 and a Massive Passive? I have the MP currently, but I am rarely using the actual bands...I mostly just hit it at whatever volume I feel best suits the color I'm looking for (different for every song). It does do a very cool job, but I just wonder if the Fearn is maybe a little more like "clear" in the lows or something? We've talked about the rounding of the lows, I know that's indicative of the tubes on some level but I've been mulling maybe going to the Fearn since usually what the Manley does best to me (biggers boosts/cuts transparently) I feel is just too much for a lot of the stuff I'm doing and a lot of mastering these days.

Also for most modern pop stuff I'm in the box, this wouldn't be for that. But I do actually use the MP a fair amount with good result in the capacity of it being a "tube box" sorta thing

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: Question for those of you using a G14 or other Gyraf gear - what level are you running at? I'm testing the buffer from this Pultec circuit (same as G14 as far as I can tell) but it's completely crunching at any reasonable level. Even when I turn my converters down to +13dBu I can't play anything at full scale without it crunching. If I back it down 3dB from there it's OK but that's super low compared to +19dBu levels and the noise floor of it is pretty high

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: If I do a sweep at -20dBFS with converters set at +19dBu I get around 1% distortion. Could be usable but would be ridiculous to need to have everything at -20dBFS. My other gear is 0.001% even at -3dBFS

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: Nothing but the SRPP amp connected to converters

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: OK so the second tube from the pair I got (tested on the same board) is giving me 12dB more and the voltage before the output cap is completely different. Still distorting long before getting much level from it but clearly at least one of the tubes isn't as it should be

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Something I have loved about the weiss EQ is the stepped frequencies and .1db steps.

I’m now using it and equilibrium (I prefer equilibrium when in the box, for whatever reason I prefer the weiss when I go outboard it matches well to me)…but having used it only for the last year it was really great as a learning tool…it is easy to hear the differences in the steps which I found made me have less options and therefore better masters (and there are more than enough options to accomplish essentially anything)

For @Nomograph Mastering it may not sound how he likes or is not flexible enough, but for me as a beginner I think it sounds great and the slightly restricted options really focus my energy where they should be

author: Rob Domos
content: I haven’t had enough free hours to keep pulling the thread, but the output from the playback of different daws null perfectly on digital loopback but on playback going out of each DAW out the DAC I can pick out blind differences between DAWs. I’ve spent so long wrestling with this and the only logical conclusion I’ve been able to come to is that they handle the passing off of the data stream to the DAC differently, ie. (And here’s where I start talking about shit I really don’t know shit about) Ableton running audio off of a midi clocking design that runs off of your macs built in clock while reason is running off of the clock built into your interface or whatever. When I asked Chat GPT it told me that they do each use various forms of clocking for playback that aren’t 1:1 the same but I have no fucking way of verifying this after hours of trying to find sources.

content: Bits are going out my DAC when I listen

author: Rob Domos
content:
A couple of things could be at play here:

1) I saw a study once where participants preferred lossy audio over lossless. Maybe that’s because the OGG rolloff was just enough to make Travis Scott’s top end bearable, or maybe it’s because people have become accustomed to the lossy sound. All that to say, you could like the sound of the loss. 

2) It’s possible that Bluetooth is less destructive to audio than a DAC the size of a tic-tac fit into a lightening cable that feeds a port that is every bit as much for charging as it is for audio

author: Stefan
content: Paris, how do you go about interfacing and auditioning multiple converters in your studio?

author: Paris Lee
content:
@Stefan 
I don’t audition different converters on every track. That would drive me insane. 
For an album that would be more of a thing…but I’ll be honest I’ll just use one converter for a while across some projects and then I’ll switch to the other one arbitrarily for a while…

(I have a Crane Song Interstellar and a Lavry Savitr
Both great All Rounders that have proven legacies  and hard to get a bad sound out of…)

I’m not a big believer that the converter is the ‘barrier’ to delivering your best work. If you’re in a room where you’re hearing what’s happening clearly, you can work. Now we all have our preferences on that ‘last 5 percent’ of sonics, which influences your decision, but if I can hear the eq and get a cohesive tight image and strong center, it doesn’t matter, I’m fine. All of that is Much more important. 

These converters are all so fucking good now. I think 15 years ago which one you had was more of a heated discussion. 

Just don’t feel the need to go off the reservation on the ones you’ve seen in the top guys racks over the years, and…DONT BUT SOME VINTAGE THING THAT COULD BREAK ON YOU!!! Get something new that’s supported. 

Maybe I over answered haha. Coffee ya know

author: Paris Lee
content:
Nice one! 
I’m gonna check this RME out then…i want a new all in one with a small footprint that kicks ass on my Desk.

Apropos of nothing 

Two Best all in one systems I’ve ever used 

1) Prism Ada 8 (sold it waaaaaaay too early in my mastering life… cuz i got sucked into the antelope hype machine.

Could totally still have been using it all this time… and do now. have an ol faithful Prism DA-2 at the spot in use (thx @Nomograph Mastering)

Dont fix what isn’t broken, kids…

2) Merging HAPI (original Ardatech AD chip card with the newer ESS Pro DA card)

…still got it! 

Got sucked into the Lavry vortex…but coming out of it…and forgot how goddamn good this was till I plugged it in recently.  
Once again…things were great. Saw a gold thing…thought…hey-I like Gold things..! Back to maturity.

Glad I brought the unit back out…
…Wanted to compare it to @huntleymiller standalone Frank Lacy build Ardatech Ad I just bought off him!!! 
the frank one, unsurprisingly, is better). 

Strap that up on the RME AES and run a simple USB cable sounds like a breath of fresh air. With the Atmos stuff, life is too complicated!!!

Tried combining both worlds after having them seperate. Mistake! 

(And yes you can DM me if you’re digging for gold and  want a Savitr and a Quintessence I’ll give a decent deal if you buy both)

author: Paris Lee
content:
Pretty dumb question here if you actually know about computers themselves-
And an eye rolling one generally-

RME released ARM Windows Drivers for non intel Windows machines. My question isn’t about what they are actually intended for (specifically designed for ‘snapdragon’ CPU’s and not for x86). But, from what i understand when you’re on parallels on Mac (yes this is not the same as a straight ARM install, it is a ‘virtualization’, got that.)

But it does use the Arm windows installation (slap me if untrue) 

I’m going to try this out and report back because, after reaading the RME ADI Pro FS manual, my eyes kinda got wide and misty as to to how fucking good this interface was designed (on so many levels) and I’d ‘like’ to just run Sequoia on an M1 Mac in parallels, if at all possible. 

This seems like maybe you have a legitimate shot of RME drivers showing up within your parallels with little fuss and computer nerdery and actually working decently…? 

Definitely NOT intending to do a computer science pivot. No one wants that! Lmao
 Does this pass a smell test/ or anyone actually run their computers off a M1 in parallels and it’s not that deep) /PM

author: Paris Lee
content:
A joy to listen to. It has a mellow sheen that’s got a perfect presence  that does *not* digititis mix elements from 3-10k. *Especially percussive ones*
That hot bright snare sample that kicks up your anxiety level and inflames your tinnitus asserts itself as being what it is, but is free of those extra panic attack additives

You are unshackled-less afraid to eq certain areas that evoke ptsd that other converters have baked into you. That 8x oversampling setting might be wrong, but the aliasing is not fucking up your whole day and making you reach for a Xanax 

Very easy to concentrate on the music and feel relaxed doing it. No notes. 

We’ll see if the benchmark stays. Not part of the ‘master plan’ i just don’t have trs xlr cables for the other RME da pair. 
But we all know the DAC 3 kicks ass so no complaints at all pitching with it right now…

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: Yeah RME is sick and this is exactly the purpose of their gear, to get out of the way and let you do what you want!

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I did at a decade of very expensive outboard, coloring things, pushing things etc

author: masteredbyjack
content: So for instance, a very clean piano track that is sparse im not letting true peaks in, because I’ve studied how that will codec convert (or a DAC can make the true peaks into real peaks when it goes to analog, etc)

author: Paris Lee
content:
Lately I’ve gotten a hold of TDR elliptical and TDR ultrasonic and find both of them very good additions 
‘Traditional Disc Mastering’ preset is solid starting point on beat oriented music. 

My new export scheme in Reaper involves upsampling the file to 96k mastering there. And using chain upsampling post converter at 192 and leaving oversampling off plugins whenever possible…placing ultrasonic after the last limiter seems to be  helpful but also something probably to be cautious with fussing too much around with other than turn if on and see if it’s better, has extra features that are above my pay grade (nyquist hard limit, dynamic gating…) 

I export out at 44/48 64 bit and get that out of the way and the chain OS still stays at 192. 

Db power amp to 24 bit triangle dither. 

Voxengo R8brain in Reaper, to me, is pretty damn good

author: Bryan DiMaio
content:
There's a lot of stuff in there that may be formed from misconceptions, like specific level and loudness values, etc
In addition to that as a mastering engineer starting out maybe try and get it all done with an EQ, a limiter, and a clipper when needed. It'll help you way more than adding many character plugins and potentially getting into the dangerous territory of adding something just to add it
